INTRODUCTION TO MONEY LAUNDERING

Australia's commitments

 

Australia is a member of the Financial Action Task Force (FATF), an

inter-governmental body whose broad aim is to develop international anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing standards. FATF issues recommendations, interpretative notes and best practice guidelines to help states combat money laundering and terrorist financing. Other member states include Canada, China, Germany, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United States.

 

Australia is also a member and permanent Co-Chair of the Asian Pacific Group on Money Laundering (APGML). The APGML is a FATF-style body for the Asia/Pacific region with its headquarters in Sydney. The APGML has 41 member states committed to following the global anti-money laundering and counter- terrorism financing standards.

 

Your organisation's key obligations under the Act are as follows:

The Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act (the Act) was passed in 2006 in response to international pressure on Australia to update its anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing measures.

 

The reforms were a major step towards:

 

•         bringing Australia in line with international standards, including those set by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF)

•         preventing and detecting money laundering and terrorism financing by meeting the needs of law enforcement agencies for targeted information about possible criminal activity and terrorism

Establish and maintain an AML/CTF program

Keep records

Conduct customer identification and verification of identity

Conduct ongoing customer due diligence

Report in relation to suspicious matters, threshold transactions and international funds transfer instructions

Australia's commitments
